text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
ADEVARUL
- Investments in mining sector this year dropped to 980 million lei from 1.94 billion lei in 1995.
- Romania to export 165,000 tonnes of sunflower oil.
- Communications Ministry said consportia Telefonica
Romania, Zephir, blueTel, MobiFon, MobilRom and Romcell would bid for two GSM licences.
- Debts of troubled private Dacia Felix SA bank raise by 1.0 billion lei a day..
- State Property Fund approved privatisation of 82 companies, of which 49 are farming equipment makers.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Trading on Romania's electronic OTC market to start on Friday.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- Bihor county to resort to army troops and students to harvest crops.
LIBERTATEA
- GSM system will break state monopoly in communications.
TINERETUL LIBER
- Romania to become member of CEFTA in the coming months.
AZI
- Irak, Sudan, Mozambique and Syria have debts worth some $2.12 billion to Romania.
General:
All newspapers report on the death of Nicu Ceausescu, youngest son of late dictator Nicolae Ceausescu.
ROMANIA LIBERA

- Opposition Democratic Party (PD) lead by ex-premier Petre Roman to contest President Ion Iliescu's candidacy for upper house of Senate as independent on list of ruling Party of Social Democracy (PDSR).
- Several PDSR county organisations threaten to resign to protest against the way the party's leading board named candidates for the November 3 parliamentary elections.
- Tow-page report on Romania's bid to join NATO.
- Romania switches to winter time on Saturday night.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI
ADEVARUL
- PD vice-president Alexandru Sassu accuse state television of alleged electoral fraud, saying two million Romanians can watch the electoral campaign only on the state television.
LIBERTATEA
- In an eight-page suppliment titled "Guide for voters" the newspaper presents the main presidential candidates and excerpts of their electoral programmes.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- The upper Senate ratified the Romanian-Hungarian treaty. ($=3,247 lei) -- Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
